title: Filipino Fish Escabeche Recipe
description: Filipino escabeche made with white fish is served with a sweet and tangy vinegar sauce flavored with fresh ginger and garlic.
body: ​ Skip to content Allrecipes Search Please fill out this field. Search the site Please fill out this field. About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines Asian Filipino Filipino Fish Escabeche 4.7 (3) 2 Reviews 2 Photos This Filipino escabeche is served with a sweet vinegar sauce with onion and red bell pepper. This recipe works well with any white fish like tilapia, cod, or halibut. Submitted by lola Updated on November 15, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 2 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 30 mins Total Time: 45 mins Servings: 4 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings 1 cup oil for frying 1 (4 ounce) whole tilapia, cleaned and scaled salt to taste 3 tablespoons olive oil 1 onion, chopped 2 cloves garlic, minced 1 red bell pepper, cut into chunks 1 (1 inch) piece ginger, thinly sliced crosswise, or to taste 1 ¼ cups water 1 cup distilled white vinegar 5 tablespoons white sugar salt and ground black pepper to taste 1 tablespoon cornstarch Directions Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Pat fish dry with a paper towel. Cut 2 to 3 slits on either side of fish; sprinkle salt on top. Fry in hot oil until browned, about 2 minutes per side. Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. Sauté onion and garlic until onion is translucent, about 5 minutes. Add red bell pepper and ginger; sauté until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Mix water, vinegar, and sugar together in a bowl; pour into onion mixture in the skillet. Cover and bring to a boil. Cook until slightly reduced, about 2 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Add cornstarch. Boil, stirring often, until sauce is thickened, about 5 minutes. Pour sauce over fish. From the Editor We have determined the nutritional value of oil for frying based on a retention value of 10% after cooking. Amount will vary depending on cooking time and temperature, ingredient density, and specific type of oil used. Add Your Photo Photos of Filipino Fish Escabeche 01 of 02 Photo by  nicolekrystyn 02 of 02 Photo by  nicolekrystyn 03/27/2023 I've never made a recipe like this before, so was excited to try something new! There was no whole tilapia at the market where I get my fish, so I opted for a big fresh piece of cod. My fillet was over 1.5lbs so I cut it into 4 pieces and fried two at a time. There was no skin so some of the fish broke up in the oil, but I was able to save all the pieces and have plenty of fish for dinner for two with some leftover. I'm wondering if the 4oz tilapia is a typo since the recipe made more than enough sauce for my 1.5lbs of fish? The only other note I would make to this recipe is to mix the cornstarch with cold water to create a slurry, since when I added the cornstarch directly to the sauce mixture clumps formed immediately. The sweet and sour flavors definitely came through and the fresh ginger really made it pop. I'm excited to try this recipe again with different fish! 1 You’ll Also Love Sinigang na Bangus (Filipino Milkfish in Tamarind Broth) 1 Rating Crab Omelet 6 Ratings Pinakbet 26 Ratings Bopis Recipe 4 Ratings Vegetable Steamed Tilapia 3 Ratings Garlic Salmon 558 Ratings Chicken Salpicao 1 Rating LaWanna's Mango Salsa on Tilapia Fillets 11 Ratings Tuna Fish Patties 26 Ratings Parchment Baked Salmon 95 Ratings Coconut Fish Curry 23 Ratings Bahamian Baked Grouper 14 Ratings Prawn Malai Curry 14 Ratings Pan-Seared Red Snapper 271 Ratings Filipino Lumpia 43 Ratings Salmon Patties with Cornmeal and Crackers 147 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: lola
instructions: Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).;Pat fish dry with a paper towel. Cut 2 to 3 slits on either side of fish; sprinkle salt on top. Fry in hot oil until browned, about 2 minutes per side.;Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. Sauté onion and garlic until onion is translucent, about 5 minutes. Add red bell pepper and ginger; sauté until fragrant, about 2 minutes.;Mix water, vinegar, and sugar together in a bowl; pour into onion mixture in the skillet. Cover and bring to a boil. Cook until slightly reduced, about 2 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Add cornstarch. Boil, stirring often, until sauce is thickened, about 5 minutes. Pour sauce over fish.
